inlineContent.text: Use a symbol style layer to configure the visual appearance of feature labels.
These features can come from vector tiles loaded by an
You can access an existing symbol style layer using the
method if you know its identifier;
property. You can also create a
new symbol style layer and add it to the style using a method such as
examples learn how to style data on your map

abstract.text: An
is a style layer that renders icon and text labels at
points or along lines on the map.
An
is a style layer that renders georeferenced raster
imagery on the map, especially raster tiles.
The property allows control over a symbol’s orientation. Note that the property
values act as a hint, so that a symbol whose language doesn’t support the
provided orientation will be laid out in its natural orientation. Example:
English point symbol will be rendered horizontally even if array value contains
single ‘vertical’ enum value. The order of elements in an array define priority
order for the placement of an orientation variant.
is an abstract superclass for style layers whose
content is defined by an
object.

Sorts features in ascending order based on this value. Features with lower sort

, features with a higher sort key will overlap over features with a

An
is a style layer that covers the entire map. Use a
background style layer to configure a color or pattern to show below all other
map content. If the style’s other layers use the Mapbox Streets source, the
background style layer is responsible for drawing land, whereas the oceans and
other bodies of water are drawn by
objects.
The transition affecting any changes to this layer’s
property.
Offset distance of icon from its anchor.
The directions in which the icon stretches to fit around the text. If the icon
image is a resizable image, the resizable areas may be stretched, while the cap
insets are always drawn at the original scale.
Part of the text placed closest to the anchor.
If true, the icon will be visible even if it collides with other previously
drawn symbols.

locations: the renderer will attempt to place
